question: What is the art and technique of making maps?
Which additive color system uses three primary colors where a value of 0 for each creates black, and a value of 255 for each creates white?
In the RGBA color model, what does the 'A' or alpha value represent?
Which subtractive color system, used for printing on paper, creates colors by absorbing parts of the light spectrum?
In the HSV color model, what property represents the intensity of a color, where less intensity creates a lighter, whiter color?
What type of map, also called a reference map, shows real-world features and is used for navigation?
What type of map visualizes a particular subject or theme, such as temperature, language, or population?
Which thematic map uses shading, colors, or patterns within predefined areas to show quantitative data?
What type of thematic map uses ancillary information to model the internal distribution of a phenomenon, refining the boundaries of a choropleth map?
Which type of map represents a continuous surface using lines of equal value (isolines) or ranges of similar values filled with color?
In cartography, what type of map uses symbols whose size corresponds directly to the magnitude of the mapped variable?
What is a thematic set of colors called that is used to represent variation, order, or different categories on a map?
Which type of color ramp is best for showing values that are above or below a central, critical value like sea level?
What is a map that accurately represents the relative position of objects and can be used as a source of data, such as a USGS topographic map?
Which map purpose category describes a map with a specific message to convey?
A map that attempts to convince the reader to have a specific opinion falls into which purpose category?
Which of the following is NOT a standard map layout element?
Which type of map covers a small area, causing features to appear large?
Which type of map covers a large area, causing features to appear small?
In map symbolization, which characteristics are best for representing quantitative information?
In map symbolization, which characteristics are best for representing qualitative information?
What is the proper ordering of GIS layers from top to bottom for effective visualization?
What is the term for a line frame placed around all the elements of a map?
What is the network of lines representing constant latitude and longitude on a map?
What is a map that does not include relief or elevation data called?
What design principle involves the visual separation of the main features (figure) from the contextual information (ground)?
What is the style, arrangement, and appearance of text on a map, including point size, line length, and typefaces?
Which font type, often used for labeling water features, is a cursive font based on calligraphic handwriting?
What typographic adjustment modifies the spacing uniformly between all characters in a block of text?
What is a two-axis grid where each grid cell or vertex has one and only one Z value?
What are lines of equal height above or below sea level on a map called?
What is the general term for lines on a map that connect points of equal value?
What type of isoline connects points of equal water depth?
What type of isoline connects points of equal time distance from a specific location?
What is the difference in elevation between adjacent contour lines on a topographic map?
What 3D technique creates three-dimensional shapes by extending 2D shapes vertically?
What is the technique of showing the topographical shape of hills and mountains using shading based on a light source?
What is the practice of coloring elevation intervals between contour lines to represent height relative to sea level?
What occurs where the shape of a surface abruptly changes in a Triangulated Irregular Network (TIN)?
What is a set of data points in a 3D coordinate system, often generated by LiDAR?
What remote sensing method uses light in the form of a pulsed laser to measure ranges on Earth?
In relief shading, what is the angle between the incoming light ray and the surface normal?
What is the angle between a vertical line (zenith) and the sun's location?
What cartographic style combines relief shading, contouring, and rock drawing to create a three-dimensional impression, famously practiced by Swiss cartographers?
What USGS program, which replaced the National Elevation Dataset (NED), is managed by the USGS to produce high-quality 3D topographic data using LiDAR?
What is the standard map scale for a modern USGS topographic map?
For cartography to be informative, it requires identification of the who, what, where, and...?
What term describes a lack of transparency, where 0% is fully transparent and 100% is not transparent at all?
In the CMYK color model, what does the 'K' stand for?
In the HSV color model, what property represents the dimension of lightness or darkness?
In the HSV color model, what property is the additive color base, determined by amounts of primary colors?
What type of map projection is best for thematic maps, especially for large areas like the US or the world?
What type of thematic map shows the distribution of a quantitative phenomenon where dots are placed to represent values at specific locations?
What type of map displays more than two sets of data on a single map?
On what type of map does the size of a symbol represent a range of values (e.g., 1-10, 11-20, 21-30)?
What type of color ramp uses a sequence of colors to indicate which values are smaller or larger than others?
What term describes the use of the internet to generate and distribute spatial data and maps, often as a service?
A map is described as a model of the earth at a...?
Which map purpose has a broad goal of showing features on the landscape as accurately as possible?
What type of map does not have a particular message to convey and is used to discover patterns?
What is the term for how well the layers and themes of a map work together visually?
Which map layout element provides information about the map's data sources, projection, author, and date?
When is it appropriate to leave a north arrow off a map or use multiple north arrows?

answers.text: When the map is at a very small scale
When the map projection causes the direction of north to vary across the map
When the map is thematic and not used for navigation
When the map is oriented with south at the top

question: What map element shows the directions of north, south, east, and west?
What cartographic principle states that large-scale maps generally have less geometric error than small-scale maps?
What are the three main types of scales that can be displayed on a map?
What type of scale begins at zero?
What type of scale begins at a point defined by the author and can progress in both directions?
What is the standard unit of measurement for map symbols and text size in cartography?
What is a map feature, such as a road or building footprint, that is independent of elevation?
What map design element refers to the arrangement of elements and whether they appear stable or unsettled?
What map design principle refers to the perceived importance of map elements, separating them into visual layers?
What map design element describes the degree to which elements are distinguishable from one another and their background?
What cartographic concept refers to making symbols the appropriate sizes so they can be easily read and understood?
What type of font has small lines at the end of strokes and is often used for graphic features like mountains or oceans?
What type of font does NOT have extending features (serifs) at the end of strokes and is often used for city names or legends?
What typographic adjustment modifies the spacing between specific pairs of characters (e.g., 'A' and 'V')?
What is a map that has been purposefully distorted for gain or to mislead the reader?
What is the general term for the height or depth of a terrain element with respect to a vertical datum?
What term refers to the changes or variation in elevation across a surface?
What is a map that displays elevation data using lines of equal height?
What type of isoline connects points of equal thickness, often used in the oil and gas industry?
What are the bold or thicker lines on a topographic map that indicate elevation and help visualize contours?
What type of contours are placed in areas where elevation change is minimal to delineate small features?
What is a depiction of terrain brightness given a terrain surface and a specified sun location, developed from a DEM?
What is the measure of land elevation relative to sea level?
What 3D model represents an object with lines, showing its structure but not surfaces?
What GIS objects store collections of 2D shapes (patches) to represent 3D objects?
What is a line perpendicular to the local surface, defined by slope and surface direction?
What is the angle between north and the sun's position, measured in a clockwise direction?
What are exact points on a map with their elevation displayed beside them?
What is an oblique view of terrain that also includes cutaway views of the subsurface?
What USGS dataset, retired in 2015 and replaced by 3DEP, produced mosaics of the best available elevation data for the US?
What are highly detailed digital models of physical objects, often developed for planning bridges or buildings?
